Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Discovering Semantic Primitives

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many words in language have meanings which require a rich and structured representational system. For instance, the meaning of "most" compares the relative sizes of two sets: a sentence like "Most musicians are happy" is true if the happy musicians outnumber the unhappy musicians. However, the representational system which supports these types of set comparisons is not well-understood. Indeed, there are often multiple ways a computational system could realize such meanings. For "most," one might compare the number of happy musicians to the number of unhappy musicians, or to half the total number of musicians (e.g. Hackl 2009, Pietroski et al. 2009). The current project aims to discover the representational system for these types of complex and abstract word meanings.

Many results in cognitive science have found that people are biased to learn concepts which are simpler for their representation system: people find it easier to learn a concept like "black chairs" from examples than the more complex "short and black chairs." The current project will teach people novel, language-like concepts. It will use a novel computational model to predict what generalizations people should make in the learning experiment according to different possible representational theories, under the assumption that representational "simplicity" influences learning. This will allow multiple representational systems to be compared to see which best fit human learning patterns.

Uncovering the basic operations which underlie linguistic representation is important for understanding the way in which the mind learns and uses complex meanings. Moreover, the representational systems which best describe human learning are likely to provide a good basis for artificial systems which use and learn natural language like humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved computational and experimental work to discover the ways in which adults build complex semantic structures in language, and the primitives they use to do so. For instance, in learning number words meanings, children discover how numerical concepts relate to the words they are taught to count with. This relationship can be expressed in a logical representation language, and our work showed how these types of logical mappings might be learned. In our modeling, we constructed several rational models of learning which showed how young language learners could discover complex word meanings like numbers from only observing their usage. This work provided computational backing to a unformalized contemporary account of number learning. We also showed how experimental results can tease apart different kinds of representational theories--ones in which adults build complex concepts with different kinds of operations.

This award also funded work studying the communicative features of human languge, in particular the way in which word lengths and ambiguity are harnessed for human communication. These results show that features of linguistic systems are in some sense rationally designed for communication, an idea consistent with the idea of rational language learners. Future work should further explore how our kinds of learning models relate to such communicative features of linguistic systems.

In general, our results help explain how some of the richness of human conceptual systems arise. People may innately have access to a small set of computational primitives, and build complex concepts from them--for instance to express linguistic concepts like the meaning of "every" and "the." An better understanding of this type of learning might eventually lead to improved interventions for language learning problems, and help design computers which can learn and use language more effectively.
